content:
Please execute the following task in my repository mcpmark-eval-zl/claude-code:

I need you to implement a comprehensive label documentation and organization workflow for the repository.

**Step 1: Create Label Documentation Issue**
Create a new issue with:
- Title containing: "Document label organization for better visual organization" and "label guide"
- Body must include:
  - A "## Problem" heading describing the need for better label documentation
  - A "## Proposed Solution" heading about creating a comprehensive label guide for different label categories
  - A "## Benefits" heading listing improved visual organization and easier issue triage
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "visual organization", "label guide", "organization"
- Labels: Initially add "enhancement" and "documentation" labels to the issue

**Step 2: Create Feature Branch**
Create a new branch called 'feat/label-color-guide' from main.

**Step 3: Create Label Documentation**
On the feature branch, create the file `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md` with:
- A "# Label Organization Guide" title
- A "## Label Categories" section with a table that MUST follow this exact format:
```markdown
| Label Name | Category | Description |
|------------|----------|-------------|
```
The table must include ALL existing labels in the repository. For each label:
- Group labels by category (e.g., issue-type, platform, area, status, performance)
- Include a description for each label

- A "## Usage Guidelines" section explaining when to use each label category

**Step 4: Apply ALL Labels to the Documentation Issue**
Update the issue you created in Step 1 by adding ALL existing labels from the repository. This serves as a visual demonstration of the label organization. The issue should have every single label that exists in the repository applied to it.

**Step 5: Create Pull Request**
Create a pull request from 'feat/label-color-guide' to 'main' with:
- Title containing: "Add label organization guide" and "visual organization"  
- Body must include:
  - A "## Summary" heading explaining the label organization documentation
  - A "## Changes" heading with a bullet list of what was added
  - "Fixes #[ISSUE_NUMBER]" pattern linking to your created issue
  - A "## Verification" section stating that all labels have been documented
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "organization guide", "visual improvement", "documentation"
- Labels: Add a reasonable subset of labels to the PR (at least 5-10 labels from different categories)

**Step 6: Document Changes in Issue**
Add a comment to the original issue with:
- Confirmation that the label documentation has been created
- Total count of labels documented
- Reference to the PR using "PR #[NUMBER]" pattern
- Keywords: "documentation created", "label guide complete", "organization complete"

Note: Based on your understanding, solve the task all at once by yourself, don't ask for my opinions on anything.

content.text: Now let me create the issue:

arguments: {"server_name": "GitHub", "category_name": "GITHUB_ISSUES", "action_name": "create", "path_params": "{\"owner\": \"mcpmark-eval-zl\", \"repo\": \"claude-code\"}", "body_schema": "{\"title\": \"Document label organization for better visual organization - label guide\", \"body\": \"## Problem\\n\\nThe repository currently lacks comprehensive documentation for our label system, making it difficult for contributors to understand the purpose and proper usage of different labels. Without clear guidance on label categories and their visual organization, issue triage becomes inconsistent and the overall repository organization suffers.\\n\\n## Proposed Solution\\n\\nCreate a comprehensive label guide that documents all existing labels in the repository, organizing them by categories such as:\\n- Issue types (bug, enhancement, documentation)\\n- Platform-specific labels (platform:linux, platform:macos, platform:windows)\\n- Area-specific labels (area:api, area:core, area:mcp, etc.)\\n- Status and workflow labels (good first issue, help wanted, wontfix)\\n- Performance-related labels (perf:memory, memory)\\n\\nThis documentation will include clear descriptions for each label category and usage guidelines to ensure consistent application across all issues and pull requests.\\n\\n## Benefits\\n\\n- **Improved visual organization**: Clear categorization makes it easier to scan and understand issue priorities at a glance\\n- **Easier issue triage**: Contributors and maintainers can quickly apply appropriate labels with clear guidelines\\n- **Consistent labeling**: Standardized approach reduces confusion and improves repository organization\\n- **Better contributor onboarding**: New contributors can understand the project structure through well-organized labels\\n- **Enhanced project management**: Visual organization enables better tracking of different types of work\\n\\nKeywords: label documentation, visual organization, label guide, organization\", \"labels\": [\"enhancement\", \"documentation\"]}", "include_output_fields": ["number", "html_url", "title"]}

| Category | Description |\\n|------------|----------|-------------|\\n| bug | Issue Type | Something isn't working |\\n| enhancement | Issue Type | New feature or request |\\n| documentation | Issue Type | Improvements or additions to documentation |\\n| question | Issue Type | Further information is requested |\\n| duplicate | Issue Type | This issue or pull request already exists |\\n| invalid | Issue Type | This doesn't seem right |\\n| area:api | Area | Issues related to API functionality |\\n| area:auth | Area | Issues related to authentication |\\n| area:core | Area | Issues related to core functionality |\\n| area:ide | Area | Issues related to IDE integration |\\n| area:mcp | Area | Issues related to MCP (Model Context Protocol) |\\n| area:model | Area | Issues related to model functionality |\\n| area:packaging | Area | Issues related to packaging and distribution |\\n| area:security | Area | Issues related to security |\\n| area:tools | Area | Issues related to tooling |\\n| area:tui | Area | Issues related to text user interface |\\n| platform:linux | Platform | Issues specific to Linux platform |\\n| platform:macos | Platform | Issues specific to macOS platform |\\n| platform:windows | Platform | Issues specific to Windows platform |\\n| good first issue | Status | Good for newcomers |\\n| help wanted | Status | Extra attention is needed |\\n| has repro | Status | Issue has a reproduction case |\\n| wontfix | Status | This will not be worked on |\\n| perf:memory | Performance | Issues related to memory performance |\\n| memory | Performance | Issues related to memory usage |\\n| external | External | Issues related to external dependencies |\\n\\n## Usage Guidelines\\n\\n### Issue Types\\nThese labels categorize the fundamental nature of the issue:\\n- **bug**: Use for defects, errors, or unexpected behavior\\n- **enhancement**: Use for feature requests and improvements\\n- **documentation**: Use for documentation-related tasks\\n- **question**: Use when seeking clarification or information\\n- **duplicate**: Use when an issue already exists\\n- **invalid**: Use for issues that don't follow guidelines or are incorrect\\n\\n### Area Labels\\nThese labels help identify which part of the codebase is affected:\\n- Use **area:** prefix to indicate the functional area\\n- Multiple area labels can be applied if an issue spans multiple components\\n- Helps with routing issues to appropriate maintainers\\n\\n### Platform Labels\\nThese labels specify platform-specific issues:\\n- Use when the issue is specific to a particular operating system\\n- Can be combined with other labels\\n- Helps prioritize platform-specific fixes\\n\\n### Status Labels\\nThese labels indicate the current state or priority of the issue:\\n- **good first issue**: Suitable for new contributors\\n- **help wanted**: Additional help needed from the community\\n- **has repro**: Issue includes reproduction steps\\n- **wontfix**: Issue will not be addressed\\n\\n### Performance Labels\\nThese labels identify performance-related issues:\\n- **perf:memory**: Specific memory performance issues\\n- **memory**: General memory usage concerns\\n- Use to prioritize optimization work\\n\\n### External Labels\\nThese labels identify issues related to external factors:\\n- **external**: Issues caused by or related to external
